Award.AwardTitle: Sustainable Scale-Up of Nanoparticle Manufacturing Using Microreactors

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanoparticles made of precious metals (gold, silver, platinum, etc.) are useful for biomedical therapies, energy generation, and improving the efficiency of chemical reactions. Current techniques for manufacturing these nanoparticles, however, rely on slow and costly laboratory-scale chemical reactions, making metal nanoparticles cost-prohibitive for their most promising applications. Reactions performed in small batches in the lab guarantee high particle quality and uniformity. This quality and uniformity would be lost if the reaction volumes were increased to the industrial scale. This award supports research in the development of microfluidic chemical reactors for generating nanoparticles. Microfluidic chemical reactors handle very small volumes of chemicals in channels that are smaller than a millimeter across. Because of their small size, they can produce nanoparticles with the same quality and uniformity as the laboratory-scale reactions currently used. The goal of the research supported by this award is to understand how to operate many microfluidic reactors simultaneously, allowing for large quantities of nanoparticles to be produced in an automated, continuous manner while maintaining the quality of these particles. The technology developed here will facilitate the efficient and sustainable industrial-scale production of metal nanoparticles. This project will be integrated with an educational outreach program that incorporates high school and community college students as active participants in the research.

While nanofabrication in microreactors is an established technology, there are several challenges that need to be overcome to make it a sustainable industrial-scale process. This research will accomplish four objectives to overcome these challenges. (1) Development of sustainable ionic-liquid based chemistry for the fabrication of Pt and Rh nanoparticles. (2) Design of microfluidic surface coatings for maximized throughput of droplet flows. (3) Implementation of new droplet merger techniques to facilitate multistep (e.g., seeded growth) nanoparticle fabrication reactions. (4) Feedback control of highly parallelized systems of microreactors to facilitate industrial-scale yields. This award will advance knowledge at the intersection of diverse fields of study, facilitating the application of techniques from chemistry, chemical engineering, and microfabrication technology to develop fundamental principles for the scale up of nanoparticle manufacturing in continuous-flow microreactors. It will lead to the development of broadly adaptable schemes for the rational assembly and control of massively parallel microfluidic reactors and techniques for performing sustainable chemistry in these systems. The goal is a science-based approach to the design of industrial-scale, sustainable microreactor manufacturing systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop tools and techniques to make microreactors practical tools for manufacturing nanoparticles. Crystalline metal nanoparticles have many applications, particularly as catalysts for energy production. However, high-quality metal nanoparticles are difficult to make at the industrial scale because industrial-scale reactors have non-uniform mixing and temperature profiles, which lead to inconsistency and lack of uniformity in the nanoparticles produced. Microscale reactors, on the other hand, are inherently uniform because of their compact dimensions; such microreactors have been demonstrated to efficiently produce high-quality nanoparticles.

In this project, we studied how to bring the uniformity and quality of microreactors to an industrial scale. We accomplished this by parallelization: operating many reactors at once. Parallel reactor operation poses several challenges that we addressed throughout the project; these are described in the Intellectual Merit section below. The project included an integrated outreach program designed to reach members of communities that have been traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering. This program is described in the Broader Impacts section below.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Droplet microreactors consist of micromachined channels in which a series of discrete droplets are formed and flowed through. The droplets contain the reagents that react to give a final project; the confined space of the droplet leads to excellent uniformity, control, and reproducibility. When droplet reactors are connected in a network for parallel operation, however, the present special challenges. In particular, pressure perturbations across the network, or uneven driving pressures, can lead to inconsistent droplet formation.

To solve this problem, we designed a microreactor geometry in which droplet size and regularity is unaffected by pressure perturbations in the network. We used these reactors to generate platinum nanoparticles. To further improve the economics and sustainability of the process, we performed the reaction using an ionic liquid solvent, which is easily reclaimable in a recycling process. We showed that over three cycles of recycling, there was no change to the quality of the nanoparticles produced.

We also explored implementations of droplet microreactors in high-temperature environments. Using conventional heating methods, we manufactured nickel nanoparticles that were shown to be effective catalysts for improving the quality of biofuels. We also showed that microwave heating could be used to produce catalytically active rhodium and rhodium-silver nanoparticles.

 

Broader Impacts:

Low-cost scalable manufacturing of high quality nanoparticles has implications for improved catalysts, electronic materials, structural composite materials, and pharmaceuticals. The route to scaling we have developed in this project has potential long-term applications impacting all of these.

The project included an integrated outreach program consisting of two primary efforts: summer internships for community college students and lab experiences for secondary school teachers. The community college program was a paid eight-week internship implemented in cooperation with Cerritos Community College in Norwalk, CA. Community college students worked alongside PhD student mentors and gained general lab experience, direct experience in the materials chemistry of nanomaterials, and practical experience in communicating and presenting scientific ideas.

 High-school teachers were invited into the lab for a four-week period in the summer. Here, they worked side-by-side with PhD students in the lab while meeting with other teachers in the program to develop lesson plans and curricula based on their laboratory experiences.
